Answer: It's a symbolic move, intended to have an outcome not obvious on first glance. 

If LA Times or Washington Post were to come out in support of Harris, would anyone be surprised? Or even care? These organizations have made their overall stance on Trump clear for years, so an overt nomination of Harris is old hat. And obviously they will not endorse Trump, or else these papers would collapse in a quantum singularity of insanity.

But ah, if they don't endorse anyone... Now they can fill that vacuum with some fearmongering about the dictator-in-waiting. Maybe with that, the non-endorsement will be more valuable than an explicit endorsement for Harris...

The truth is... Nobody knows. There's a ton of ratfuckery around polling, which has traditionally relied on run of the mill politics and feedback from voters to Inform their numbers.

Now? There is more misinformation and misdirection than anything. Voters from one party register as the other to vote during that groups primaries, in hopes of swaying the candidates chosen for the general election. 

"October Surprise" has been replaced with muckraking media for ratings, with each side ginning up their base with reports that make the race seem tighter than it may be (because like a good football game, people keep watching until the end of its close, but people change the channel during a blowout).

This doesn't even take into account people who are actively lying to poll workers, because why not? 

All in all, the elections, while including millions of people, typically come down to a few counties in key swing states: popular vote means nothing with electoral college, and if the candidates win these swing counties in these swing states. They win the election. 

And all the pollsters and media can do is make an educated guess on how those areas will vote (hence. The "swing" of it all.

Answer: Dr. Phil’s rise to game is an interesting story. First off, he is not a medical doctor. He does have a PhD in clinical psychology, which is not easy to do, but the title of “doctor Phil” definitely played off a perception of him being a medical doctor

His rise to fame started (or was massively boosted) when he was a guest on Oprah’s show. He would go onto have his own reality TV show, which despite its pretense and setting is a lot closer to something like the Bachelor or Flavor of Love than it was to being something about him genuinely wanting to help people. The scenarios were heavily curated and fabricated ahead of time. I love some good trash TV, but I wouldn’t be looking for his phone number if I had some serious mental health issues.

Blaming his relevance (I am using that loosely) on Oprah is like thinking of it as a domino effect where each domino hit a bigger one and eventually we get to these past elections where a C or D tier celebrity is endorsing Trump

Phil also has a long list of debauchery under his belt. Check out the behind the bastards podcast if you’re curious

There's a much simpler explanation. 

The vast majority of black people circa 1870 lived in the south. The south, both white and black, had watermelon and fried chicken as major cultural foods, and watermelons grow really well. 

Then the great migration happened when the KKK got real nuts starting in the 20th century and millions of black people moved to the west coast, rust belt, and northeast cities where labor was needed. They took the watermelon and fried chicken culture with them and Northerners ascribed them to blackness rather than southernness.

Answer: back in the 90's and 00's there was a big push for gay rights, specifically the right to marry. Even as recently as 2008, Deep Blue California defined marriage as between one man and one woman.

Popular opinion changed VERY quickly, to where today most people on either side of the political aisle accept that gay people are allowed to marry. There are some hold-outs in the Republican Party, and unfortunately they are the most vocal, but they are a minority.

Well, all that money and activist energy doesn't just go away when the problem goes away, so the radials on the Left moved to the next issue: trans rights.

Most (not all) people on the Right have a "live and let live" approach to trans people, but the issue came when the Left started targeting children with things like drag queen story hour, giving children hormone blockers without parental consent, and allowing people with a penis access to women's locker rooms. 

The movement that started as a quest for equal rights has jumped the shark and started trying to manipulate and influence children, so the Right has felt the need to push back.

“Answer: “ The betting odds showing Trump is a likely victor are due to 2 very closely related factors.

1.	⁠These numbers have been highlighted and circulated via supporters of Trump. Polymarket for example has been advertising very heavily this past month on Trump-supporting platforms.
2.	⁠A plurality of these bettors are men and/or trump supporters. The idea is, that if betting markets show a Trump victory, that will increase support and likelihood of his victory.

In markets like these that have to do with sports or current events, trends typically follow an observable pattern. We’ve seen a decline in his percentage recently, with it topping out at around 66 a week to two weeks ago.

This is due to a sell-off, where people are satisfied with their winnings having gone up in value, and don’t want to risk the possibility of their bets being called against a Trump loss.

For example: if you bought in September 24’ for $.25, and sale price is around $.75 the day before election, you can mark a 200% increase by selling off your position. This could be a very large pay-out depending on how much was bet.

Tl;dr, these numbers don’t mean much in the grand scheme of things, but they do identify a high-confidence among those placing the bets that Trump will be the president.

Answer: I mean... where do you live? I bet either your country, or a neighboring one, has probably elected somebody between "far-right" and "actual fascist" to whatever the Head of the Executive is. It's a global phenomenon, so looking at any one country is foolish. 

What is the one thing that's universal now? Misinformation. The far-right's support is built on fear, hatred, and anger -- all of which is very easy to create if you're willing to lie and people are too stupid/busy/apathetic to actually look things up. 

Progressives, conversely, have to tell the truth (or at least something resembling it). Even worse than that, they have to do so about complicated issues (not just social issues like gender, but things like how hard the economy is to deal with and why taxes and social welfare programs are good things). 

Nuance loses out to nonsense, because the latter can be produced at a near infinite pace.

This is the thing that frustrates me and I think was ultimately the downfall of the DNC and all democrats in general this this year. Even before last night, the rhetoric was that if you vote republican you’re a racist, a fascist, an idiot, poorly educated, a redneck, etc. and while some of those may or may not be true in some cases, its a major failure to not look outside of those factors, see what legitimate reason someone might be prone to vote republican and appeal to those issues specifically to understand what the majority of Americans want, not just suburban and urban citizens. Why the hell would someone who’s planning to vote republican switch to the party who’s leaders and/or voters go out of the way to call them uneducated garbage?

American here, and I agree. I am in a \*very* left-leaning city. I've seen that rhetoric for well over a decade: If you're white, you're privileged and benefit from the system regardless of your income level. If you're not a part of Antifa or support them, you're racist. If you're white, you don't understand the struggles of people of color. (Never mind that [U.S. history shows otherwise,](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Racism_in_the_United_States#European_Americans) but that's a comment for another day.) If you're straight, you're either an ally or supporter of the LGBTQA community and LGBTQA rights, or you're the enemy--no middle ground.

...after seeing that, you have to wonder what's the point in voting for a party that tells you you're in power and evil, or automatically their enemy, even though many people regardless of skin color, gender, and sexual orientation are just trying to make it from paycheck to paycheck. Bernie Sanders is right: The Democrats turned their backs on a large segment of their voting base that they used to champion: Poor and middle-class white people, many of whom live in central states. The result was visible in yesterday's election.
